title: Dad with rare cancer needs £50,000 to get to only medical team that can treat him
text:
A dad with an ultra-rare cancer is trying to raise money for treatment abroad (Chad Alexander)

A young father with an extremely rare form of cancer is desperate to travel to the States for life-saving treatment.

Chad Alexander is suffering from Renal Medullary Carcinoma (RMC), a highly aggressive and rare form of cancer found almost exclusively in young patients with the sickle cell trait.

The cancer cannot currently be treated by the NHS and the only two other people in the UK he has found with the cancer had to fund their own treatment. One has already died.

The 30-year-old told Metro.co.uk about the profound effect the diagnosis has had on his life.

The DJ from Basingstoke said: ‘There’s practical stuff like not being able to work, of course.

‘Emotionally, just knowing you have cancer by itself is bad, but figuring out it is this type of rare cancer is terrible.’

Chad with his partner Anita and children Milan and Rome (Chad Alexander)

Chad, who lives with his children’s nurse partner Anita and children Rome, four, and Milan, one, has been unable to work since he first got sick.

Along with the money for his treatment, he hopes to raise awareness of this obscure disease.

Chad is fundraising towards a £50,000 goal in order to access cutting-edge treatment at the MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas, the only place in the world he has found that has successfully treated a patient with the cancer.,

The fundraising page describes how ‘everything changed’ since he first noticed blood in his urine in June.

Tumours were found in his kidney and lung, which required a six-hour surgery to remove them, along with his left kidney, spleen, the tail of his pancreas and part of his diaphragm.

Doctors carried out a six-hour surgery to remove his tumours (Chad Alexander)

After receiving the official devastating diagnosis on Friday, Chad scoured the internet for more information on this disease he’d never heard of.

‘There is not much about research about this disease in the world, and not much that came back in the UK,’ he said.

‘Even on that website where you type up your symptoms, nothing comes up.’

Through his research, Chad got in touch with Cora Connor, who set up the outreach organisation RMC Support after her brother was diagnosed with the condition.

She recommended the doctor who had successfully treated her brother as Chad’s best medical chance.

Chad is very eager to raise awareness of this rare disease (Chad ALexander)

But just an initial appointment with his specialist costs the equivalent of £20,000, and that is before travel or any treatment.

Advertisement

Chad said that there are only two other people in the UK who have had RMC and one recently lost his battle.

He added: ‘I need to raise awareness about it, particularly for people with the sickle cell trait.

‘I have had lots of conversations about it with people living with it, or partners of those who’ve passed away.

‘I do not know whether anyone is as visible as myself.’

He continued: ‘I need to get to get the treatment and get better, but also to use this as a platform.’
description: A dad diagnosed with an extremely rare form of cancer is trying to raise £50,000 to get the cutting-edge treatment he needs in the States.
